newsitem.title: USA: Sears close to settlements on credit card flap.
newsitem.headline: Sears close to settlements on credit card flap.

text.p: Sears, Roebuck & Co., seeking to put to rest a flap over its method of collecting credit card debt, said Tuesday it has reached preliminary settlements with consumers and state and federal regulators.
The agreements were still subject to negotiations and require the approval of the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Massachusetts among others, Sears said in a court filing.
The agreements would resolve claims that the retailer's method of collecting debt from Sears credit card holders who had filed for bankruptcy protection was illegal.

The dispute came to light during proceedings in Massachusetts bankruptcy court this spring. It threatened to tarnish the retailer's credibility just five years after it was rocked by a scandal over its selling of auto parts to customers who didn't need them.
Sears, however, quickly acknowledged it had mishandled the so-called reaffirmation agreements with customers by failing to file them in bankruptcy court.
In April, the Hoffman Estates, Ill.-based retailer voluntarily offered to repay consumers who signed the mishandled agreements and to give them each a $100 gift certificate.

Sears, the nation's second-largest retailer, said the pending settlements would resolve legal proceedings with consumers in several civil lawsuits, representatives for the attorneys general in 39 states and the U.S. Federal Trade Commission.

The retailer said it was scheduled to meet Wednesday with federal prosecutors. The U.S. Justice Department was expected to file a status report with the Massachusetts bankruptcy court on a potential criminal investigation by Thursday.
But the U.S. attorney for Massachusetts, Donald Stern, has asked the bankruptcy court to delay any settlement Sears proposes.
On Tuesday, a spokeswoman for Stern said that if a settlement were approved, it could affect Stern's pending investigation of Sears.
"There's a double jeopardy issue involved" for the prosecution, said spokeswoman Amy Rindskopf.

Sears spokesman Ron Culp said the company has not determined how much a settlement will cost. Sears has been scouring records between 1992 and 1997 involving 500,000 repayment agreements with credit card customers to calculate its liability.
The company's court filing was designed to bring up to date a Massachusetts bankruptcy judge who is scheduled to hold a hearing Thursday at which Sears hoped to present an agreement for approval.

Meanwhile, Sears said it reached an agreement in principle covering compensation, penalties and other issues with the Massachusetts attorney general, who has headed a group representing 39 states in the negotiations.
The pact was being presented to the 39 attorneys general for formal approval, Sears said in the filing.
A spokesman for Massachusetts Attorney General Scott Harshbarger said the deal had not been completed. "There is not an official settlement with Sears," said spokesman John Lamontagne.
A consent order has been reached with the Federal Trade Commission, which could approve the deal Wednesday, Sears said.

In addition to settlement costs, the U.S. bankruptcy judge could order Sears to pay punitive damages. But in its filing, Sears said it may be protected against court-imposed fines by laws barring multiple government punishments for the same offence.
Sears' stock rose 50 cents to $49.25 on the New York Stock Exchange.
